<pre class="lang-py s-code-block"><code class="hljs language-python"><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> django.utils.datastructures <span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> SortedDict

<span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title function_">sortedDictByKey</span>(<span class="hljs-params">self,data</span>):
    <span class="hljs-string">"""Sorted dictionary order by key"""</span>
    sortedDict = SortedDict()
    <span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> data:
        <span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">isinstance</span>(data, <span class="hljs-built_in">dict</span>):
            sortedKey = <span class="hljs-built_in">sorted</span>(data.keys())
            <span class="hljs-keyword">for</span> k <span class="hljs-keyword">in</span> sortedKey:
                sortedDict[k] = data[k]
    <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> sortedDict
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/a/39424969/1150683">As pointed out by Dilettant</a>, Python 3.6 will now <em>keep the order</em>! I thought I'd share a function I wrote that eases the sorting of an iterable (tuple, list, dict). In the latter case, you can sort either on keys or values, and it can take numeric comparison into account. <strong>Only for &gt;= 3.6!</strong></p>
<p>When you try using sorted on an iterable that holds e.g. strings as well as ints, sorted() will fail. Of course you can force string comparison with str(). However, in some cases you want to do <em>actual</em> numeric comparison where <code>12</code> is smaller than <code>20</code> (which is not the case in string comparison). So I came up with the following. When you want explicit numeric comparison you can use the flag <code>num_as_num</code> which will try to do explicit numeric sorting by trying to convert all values to floats. If that succeeds, it will do numeric sorting, otherwise it'll resort to string comparison.</p>
<p>Comments for improvement welcome.</p>
<pre class="lang-py s-code-block"><code class="hljs language-python"><span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title function_">sort_iterable</span>(<span class="hljs-params">iterable, sort_on=<span class="hljs-literal">None</span>, reverse=<span class="hljs-literal">False</span>, num_as_num=<span class="hljs-literal">False</span></span>):
    <span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title function_">_sort</span>(<span class="hljs-params">i</span>):
      <span class="hljs-comment"># sort by 0 = keys, 1 values, None for lists and tuples</span>
      <span class="hljs-keyword">try</span>:
        <span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> num_as_num:
          <span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> i <span class="hljs-keyword">is</span> <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>:
            _<span class="hljs-built_in">sorted</span> = <span class="hljs-built_in">sorted</span>(iterable, key=<span class="hljs-keyword">lambda</span> v: <span class="hljs-built_in">float</span>(v), reverse=reverse)
          <span class="hljs-keyword">else</span>:
            _<span class="hljs-built_in">sorted</span> = <span class="hljs-built_in">dict</span>(<span class="hljs-built_in">sorted</span>(iterable.items(), key=<span class="hljs-keyword">lambda</span> v: <span class="hljs-built_in">float</span>(v[i]), reverse=reverse))
        <span class="hljs-keyword">else</span>:
          <span class="hljs-keyword">raise</span> TypeError
      <span class="hljs-keyword">except</span> (TypeError, ValueError):
        <span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> i <span class="hljs-keyword">is</span> <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>:
          _<span class="hljs-built_in">sorted</span> = <span class="hljs-built_in">sorted</span>(iterable, key=<span class="hljs-keyword">lambda</span> v: <span class="hljs-built_in">str</span>(v), reverse=reverse)
        <span class="hljs-keyword">else</span>:
          _<span class="hljs-built_in">sorted</span> = <span class="hljs-built_in">dict</span>(<span class="hljs-built_in">sorted</span>(iterable.items(), key=<span class="hljs-keyword">lambda</span> v: <span class="hljs-built_in">str</span>(v[i]), reverse=reverse))
      
      <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> _<span class="hljs-built_in">sorted</span>
      
    <span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">isinstance</span>(iterable, <span class="hljs-built_in">list</span>):
      sorted_list = _sort(<span class="hljs-literal">None</span>)
      <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> sorted_list
    <span class="hljs-keyword">elif</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">isinstance</span>(iterable, <span class="hljs-built_in">tuple</span>):
      sorted_list = <span class="hljs-built_in">tuple</span>(_sort(<span class="hljs-literal">None</span>))
      <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> sorted_list
    <span class="hljs-keyword">elif</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">isinstance</span>(iterable, <span class="hljs-built_in">dict</span>):
      <span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> sort_on == <span class="hljs-string">'keys'</span>:
        sorted_dict = _sort(<span class="hljs-number">0</span>)
        <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> sorted_dict
      <span class="hljs-keyword">elif</span> sort_on == <span class="hljs-string">'values'</span>:
        sorted_dict = _sort(<span class="hljs-number">1</span>)
        <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> sorted_dict
      <span class="hljs-keyword">elif</span> sort_on <span class="hljs-keyword">is</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">not</span> <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>:
        <span class="hljs-keyword">raise</span> ValueError(<span class="hljs-string">f"Unexpected value <span class="hljs-subst">{sort_on}</span> for sort_on. When sorting a dict, use key or values"</span>)
    <span class="hljs-keyword">else</span>:
      <span class="hljs-keyword">raise</span> TypeError(<span class="hljs-string">f"Unexpected type <span class="hljs-subst">{<span class="hljs-built_in">type</span>(iterable)}</span> for iterable. Expected a list, tuple, or dict"</span>)
</code></pre>

<p>If your values are integers, and you use Python 2.7 or newer, you can use <a href="http://docs.python.org/py3k/library/collections.html#collections.Counter" rel="noreferrer"><code>collections.Counter</code></a> instead of <code>dict</code>. The <code>most_common</code> method will give you all items, sorted by the value.</p>
204: <p>Normally you cant update a page from a servlet. The client (browser) has to request an update. Either the  client loads a whole new page or it requests an update to a part of an existing page. This technique is called Ajax.</p>
205:
<p><strong>Branch prediction.</strong></p>
<p>With a sorted array, the condition <code>data[c] &gt;= 128</code> is first <code>false</code> for a streak of values, then becomes <code>true</code> for all later values. That's easy to predict. With an unsorted array, you pay for the branching cost.</p>
